forumNotes.author: erwan.l
forumNotes.content:
Hi There,  

I did give it a try.  

It is disk virtualisation and therefore very similar to what does winvblock and firadisk or boot manager from win7.  

Pros:  
you deal with vhd files which winvblock and firadisk cannot do  
image file does not have to be contiguous as with firadisk and winvblock  
you can use xp within your vhd which boot manager cannot (win7 / w2k8 only)  
you can install straight to a disk image which firadisk/winvblock wont do (you need to clone)  

cons:  
you need grub (i chained it from grub4dos)  
the vboot driver is a bit difficult to install (i could not do it during install, had to inject it offline \& manually)  
i could not re use my old vhd's which means there might be some constraint on the vhd format / version  
it handles "only" vhd file : handling other formats like img, vdi would be nice  

My conclusion : if you dont have win7 and/or if you have xp/w2k3 vhd's, this is a very nice tool to have.  

Regards,  
Erwan.  

![Posted Image](http://erwan.l.free.fr/tools/vboot.jpg)

forumNotes.author: Icecube
forumNotes.content:
> - can Grub2 be used directly with Vboot instead of chainloading Grub via Grub4DOS. Why Grub is required for Vboot?  
The boot loader of Vboot is just grub2 with an additional module vhd.mod that can read vhd files:  
> 4.2.2 Configure grub.cfg  
>
> A sample grub.cfg file is placed in c:\\vboot\\grub directory (or d:\\vboot\\grub depending on where you have copied the files). This is the GRUB2 configuratrion file to load operating systems. Inside this file, the vhd file path is hard coded, and thus you have to modify it.  
>
> grub.cfg is a text file that you can use notepad to open and modify. The relevant portion is shown below:  
>
> menuentry "VHD Mint 9, Linux 2.6.32-21-generic" {  
> insmod vhd  
> vhd vhd0 (hd0,1)/mint-9/mint-9-gnome-i386.vhd --partitions  
> linux (vhd0,1)/boot/vmlinuz-2.6.32-21-generic root=/dev/sda1 vloop=/mint-9/mint-9-gnome-i386.vhd quiet splash  
> initrd (vhd0,1)/boot/initrd.img-2.6.32-21-generic  
> }  
>
> menuentry groups a specific operating system. The first line insmod vhd inserts our vhd.mod module to the boot loader. vhd.mod is a GRUB2 module that treats a vhd file as hard disk, and allows GRUB2 to read files from the vhd. For example, the Linux kernel and initrd are loaded from the vhd file, as configured above.
http://www.vmlite.com/index.php/forums/17-vboot/2495-linux-mint-9-vhd-available-for-download

You can also boot VHD files with **Plop VHD Loader** .  
> The Plop VHD Loader makes it possible to start an operating system from the VHD file without Windows. Only plpvhd.bin is required to load and boot the VHD file. No OS specific startup files (os loader, kernel, ...) must be stored on the real partition. The operating system on the VHD file must be Windows/Linux that is able to run native (without virtual machine) from a VHD file. DOS is able to run without modifications.
http://www.plop.at/en/vhdloader.html  

Currently is only works for VHD files on primary FAT32 partitions, but on the other hand, it is only 2991 bytes in size.  
It is just a side project ATM for the developer, and I don't see a lot of response so it probably won't be improved (if needed), unless you try it and report back ![:fine:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/ok.gif).

If I may, the vboot is TWO different things together:  

* a loader (seemingly GRUB2 based)
* a service to access the image in windows NT based systems

Since, as said before, a .VHD is nothing but a RAW image with appended a footer, ANY bootloader/bootmanager capable of mapping an image will work.  
Then, you need a service in Windows to access the image (please read as Firadisk or WinVblock - or vbootdisk.sys ![:juggler:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/sporty98.gif) )
